Adviserate ■ary 24, 1947. / Regarding the newspaper statement made ifi Tehran referred to in your D.O. No.C/24Sedated 23rd February, is it possible that they referred to their own school? There is a Persian school in Manama which has existed for about 25 years and in the past we used occasionally to have some trouble with its authorities. They took to marching about with Persian flags, which we stopped, and I have reason to believe that certainly at one time the school received some assistance from Tehran. 2. Brief facts about our own schools are as follows:- There are nine boy* schools in Bahrain run by the Bahrain Government, of these nine is a Secondary school, four are primary schools, one a Technical school and four are village schools. In all schools, except the Secondary school, education is entirely free. Boys of all nationalities, including Persians, are admitted to all the schools. Arabic, the language of the country, is used in the schools. At the end of last term there were 1800 boys attending the Government schools. In addition the Government maintains a large hostel which provides accommodation for 50 boarders. The Director of Education for the last 18 months has been an Arab of Bahrain. There are five girls T schools where free, primary, education is provided and all nationalities attend, these are paid for entirely by the Government. The Confidential. 2 /—2 number of girls attending these schools at the end of last term was 1300. There are also two religious schools, Sunni and Shia, which are paid for by the Government. The expenditure by the Bahrain Government on education last year was Ks.5,68,754/-. In addition to Government schools there are in Bahrain, a Mission school for girls, two private Arab schools for boys, a Persian boys f school and numerous Matawaa schools. * 3. Dalrymple Belgrave, Esquire, C.B.E., Adviser to the Government of Bahrain, Bahrain, Persian Gulf. To His Britannic Majesty’s Political Agent Bahrain. Sir I have the honour to inform you that His Highness views with grave concern the increase in the number of Persians who are now residing in Bahrain. In view of the present condition he considers that any increase in the Persian minority in Bahrain may have serious consequences in future. It is his wish to reduce the number of Persians who are now living in Bahrain and he therefore suggests that in future no permission should be granted to Persians resident here to visit Persia unless they are returning to their own country in order to stay there. His Highness thinks that if Persians are not allowed to go and come freely between Bahrain and Persia many of them may prefer to go to Persia rather than to continue living here. I have the honour to be Sir Your most obedient servant Adviser to the GovernmentNo. C/1S5. POLITICAL AGENCY BAHRAIN. The 10th of February, 1948. No. C/211 The 17th of February, 1943 Dear Belgrave. • You will remember that we spoke this morning about the question of Persians coming to Bahrain. Another aspect of it has cropped up. I refer to the Persians allowed to enter Bahrain on landing permits issued by the British representative (now Vice-Consul) at Bushire - the last reference to which appears to be your memorandum No. 1343-15 dated the 23rd June, 1946. 2. The position now appears to be that the Vice- Consul, Bushire, refers to me before issuing a landing permit for a person whom he recommends for treatment in Bahrain, but we have not completely reverted to the pro cedure which was in force prior to April, 1944, as I do not think I refer to you but, at my own discretion, inform the Vice-Consul, Bushire, whether he may issue the landing permit or not. T am as anxious as you are that the number of Persians should not increase in Bahrain by immigration, and particularly by using alleged sickness as an excuse for entering and staying here. I shall, therefore, do my best to scrutinise carefully all recommendations by the Vice-Consul and reject those which do not seem to be genuine. Nevertheless, if you would prefer that all such recommendations be referred to you, I would do so, though, for the reasons stated, T doubt whether the extra office work involved is necessary. Will you let me know whether you want them referred to you or not? 3. T doubt whether Easey, the present Vice-Consul, who is a doctor would recommend any but genuine cases. Yours sincerely. C.D. mods.abstract: This file contains correspondence between British officials (primarily Charles Belgrave, Adviser to Government of Bahrain, and Cornelius James Pelly, Britain's Political Agent in Bahrain) about a number of issues related to the Persian community in Bahrain.The correspondence includes discussions regarding an article that appeared in a Tehran newspaper about education in Bahrain, the number of Persians resident in Bahrain and the means by which Persian nationals enter Bahrain.On folios 34-35 the file contains a notice (in English and Arabic) entitled 'Defence Regulations made under the Persian Gulf States (Emergency) Order in Council, 1939'. The notice was signed by Charles Geoffrey Prior, Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, 12 September 1939, and issued by the Political Agency in Bahrain on 15 September 1939.
